Distinctive redox properties and structural defects have made ceria a desirable choice for selective hydrogenation reactions for a wide array of hydrocarbons. In this work, we have studied – via density functional theory (DFT) calculations - selective hydrogenation of 1,3-butadiene into 1-butene over ceria catalyst. This reaction entails strategic applications in petroleum industries. Adsorption and surface energies for various co-adsorbed 1,3-butadaiene/hydrogen configurations were computed based on the ab initio atomistic thermodynamic formalism. The thermodynamically most stable configurations correspond to surfaces with high hydrogen surface coverage. This finding coincides with the commonly deployed high ratio of hydrogen to hydrocarbons in hydrogenation reactions over ceria. A consistent decrease in binding energies of multiple 1,3-butadiene adsorptions (per adsorbed molecule) is ascribed to a noticeable surface relaxation effects rather than to lateral interactions between adjacent adsorbed molecules. The partial hydrogenation route 1,3-butadiene →1-butene proceeds via accessible energy barriers and involves hydrogen transfer from OH* groups to surface-unbounded carbon sites. Desorption of the formed 1-butene constitutes a bottleneck in the partial hydrogenation route. The occurrence of full hydrogenation into n-butane is unfeasible in view of the high energy barrier encountered in the final hydrogen migration step to a surface-bounded carbon atom. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Selective Hydrogenation 1,3-Butadiene Ceria DFT 1 Introduction 1,3-Butadiene (C4H6, or BD for short) is the simplest compound in the diolefins group. Exposure to BD causes sever environmental and health issues [1]. Steam cracking process in ethylene production is reported to be the main source of BD (as a side-product), worldwide [2]. In steam cracking, saturated hydrocarbons (mainly ethane and naphtha) are deployed as feedstock for production of lighter olefins such as ethylene and propylene [3]. BD is obtained at the product fractionation stage where lighter products (C1 to C4 streams) are separated. Industrially, BD has a profound detrimental effect as a catalyst poisoning agent in petrochemical processes of olefins [4]. Therefore, finding alternative pathways for converting BD to other species has long been explored. In this regard, selective catalytic hydrogenation is an efficient method to reduce the load of BD, in a process that involves the activation of non-polar H2 [5]. Selective hydrogenation of BD to butenes/butane has been a focal topic in catalysis research. For instance, Lee et al. [6] modified Pd/SiO2 catalysts with TiO2 via excess wetness impregnation method to investigate its capability for BD hydrogenation. Okumura et al. [7] prepared alumina supported gold catalysts via different methods (gas/liquid phase grafting, deposition precipitation, and impregnation) to study BD's hydrogenation in a fixed bed quartz reactor. Bimetallic catalysts were also applied in the partial hydrogenation of BD. For instance, Pd and Pd-Sn catalysts supported on different alumina phases (α and θ/α) [8], were applied for selective hydrogenation of BD in a fixed bed reactor at the atmospheric pressure. It was also shown that unlike bimetallics, monometallic catalyst did not display the desired selectivity and led to butane production. In another study [9], Au-Pd/Al2O3 catalysts were found to be more successful in the selective hydrogenation of BD in the presence of propene at lower temperature (around 400 K) compared to single metallic catalysts. However, in terms of selectivity, Au/Al2O3 catalysts exhibited more desirable performance. Underlying mechanisms for the selective hydrogenation of BD into 1-butene were investigated using density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The occurrence of the partial hydrogenation was attributed to the dynamically driven 1-butene's desorption after the second hydrogenation step, which prevented full hydrogenation or re-adsorption of products [10, 11]. Among notable metal oxides in catalytic hydrogenation reactions is CeO2, or ceria. Most surface-assisted reactive properties of ceria-based materials originate from its capacity to switch its oxidation state between the two extreme limits, Ce4+ and Ce3+ [12]. The facile reducibility of ceria is enhanced when doped with a wide array of metallic constituents such as Zr, Hf, Ni or Ir [13]. While most catalytic applications of ceria materials have focused on reforming reactions for CO2 valorisation, they have also emerged as potent catalysts in a wide spectra of hydrogenation reactions that span alkynes [14], phenolic compounds [15], and alkylbenzene [16]. Ceria doped with trivalent cations were shown to be particularly effective in the semi-hydrogenation of acetylene and methylacetylene at temperature as low as 373 K [17]. Central to proposed reaction mechanisms is that metallic cations enhance the creation of oxygen vacancies, that in turn facilitates dissociative uptake of hydrogen molecules [12, 18]. However, stand-alone ceria surfaces displayed a profound capacity toward partial hydrogenation of acetylene into ethene at relatively modest operating conditions [19]. To the best of our knowledge, literature does not present an experimental or theoretical account into the highly plausible neat ceria-driven partial hydrogenation of the industrially important BD molecules. In this work, we have investigated – via DFT calculations – thermo-kinetic aspects as well as corresponding electronic factors that underline selective hydrogenation of BD into 1-butene over a neat ceria catalyst. The prime objective of the study is two-fold; firstly, to report thermodynamic stability trends for adsorbed BD/H2 configurations (as the first step in the hydrogenation reactions); and secondly, to illustrate the mechanistic origin for the occurrence of selective partial hydrogenation. 2 Computation details 2.1 The DFT calculation methodology Structures optimization and energy calculations for adsorbed hydrogen and BD configuration were performed utilizing the Vienna ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP) [20]. Projector augmented wave method (PAW) was employed to represent the spin-polarised electronic computations and the core-valence interactions [21]. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) functional of Perdew and Wang (PW91) was used to describe the electron exchange and the electronic-energy correlation effect [22]. The energy cut-off of the plane wave basis set was fixed at 400 eV. Integration of the irreducible part of the Brillion zone was carried out based on an automatic κ-points mesh generation of 3 × 3 × 1. Dispersion interactions were accounted for via applying the Grimme's D2 method a global scaling factor of 0.75 [23]. Overall, applying a vdW functional exerts a minor change in computed adsorption energies herein due to the formation of genuine chemical bonds between the adsorbates and the surface. Reproducing the experimental band gap of ceria based on the adapted PW91 DFT functional requires deploying a U value of 4.5 eV [24]. Hence the DFT + U [25] approach was considered in all calculations. Optimized transition states and reaction barriers were attained using the complete linear synchronous and quadratic synchronous transit LST/QST method [26] as implemented in the CASTEP code [27]. The underlying computational approach is described in detail in our recent study on the catalyzed evolution of syngas evolution over Zr-CeO2 decorated surfaces [28]. Computed vibrational frequencies as listed in Supplementary materials (SM) confirm the nature of transition states in displaying a single imaginary frequency along the designated reaction pathway. Calculations of transition structures deploy a 2 × 1 unitcell. Merits of using the LST/QST over the commonly deployed NEB method in computing reaction barriers is well documented in the literature [29]. Atomic partial charges for the first layers in surfaces were computed using the Mulliken formalism [30]. 2.2 Structures Stoichiometric ceria configurations were modelled by 2 × 2 unit-cells (comprising of 48 Ce and 96 O atoms) with three O-Ce-O consecutive layers terminated along the (111) direction. Adjacent images along the z-direction were separated by at least 18 Å vacuum thickness. All layers together were also allowed to fully relax to their equilibrium position. A test on one structure (B-1) with fixing the bottommost o-Ce-O layer has changed its binding energy by less than 2%. Fig. 1 . shows side-view of a ceria (111) in a vacuum slab. The surface contains sixteen surface O sites. Coverage by BD molecules and hydrogen atoms were thoroughly considered with the underlying aim to investigate the thermodynamically most stable structures at varying loads of the two adsorbates. Due to the voluminous of the BD molecule and to minimize the lateral interaction between adjacent adducts, a maximum of four molecules can be positioned above the surface. Thus, the structures B-1, B-2, B-3, and B-4 denote configurations with one, two, three, and four adsorbed butadiene molecules; respectively. Likewise, coverage by hydrogen atoms i.e., Ө H can principally vary between 0 ML and 1 ML. For instance, a H-0.75 structure denote a configuration where 75% of surface O* sites are occupied by hydrogen atoms. Configurations with co-adsorption of hydrogen atoms and 1,3-butadiene molecules are denoted analogously. For example, the configuration B-1-H-0.20 signifies a structure with one adsorbed BD molecule while ∼ 20% of the remaining O* sites are occupied by hydrogen atoms (i.e., OH* sites). Table 1 enlists description of all considered structures while Figure 2 portrays the optimized geometries of the B-1-H-0.20 as an illustrative example. 2.3 Ab initio atomistic thermodynamics Surface free energies (as a function of temperature and pressure) are calculated based on the formalism of ab initio atomistic thermodynamics [31]. Chemical potential of adsorbed species over the surface are calculated from basic thermodynamics equation as: (1) Δ μ ( T , p ) = μ ( T , p 0 ) − μ ( T 0 , p 0 ) + R T l n ( p p 0 ) where Δ μ denotes the difference in chemical potential of the species, R corresponds to the gas constant. T and p represent temperature and pressure and T0 and p0 are indicators of standard conditions (298.15 K and 1 atm). Figure 3 plots chemical potentials of gaseous hydrogen and BD molecules at the standard atmospheric pressure and between 300 – 1500 K. Surface free energies Δ G a d as a function of the operating chemical potential are computed by applying equations 2 while equation 3 affords the computation of the absolute surface free energies Δ G a b s a d (at 0 K and 0 atm): (2) Δ G a d = 1 A [ E t o t a l − E n e a t − 1 2 x ( E H 2 D F T + E H 2 Z P E + Δ μ H 2 ) − y ( E C 4 H 6 D F T + E C 4 H 6 Z P E + Δ μ C 4 H 6 ) ] (3) Δ G a b s a d = 1 A [ E t o t a l − E n e a t − 1 2 x ( E H 2 D F T + E H 2 Z P E ) − y ( E C 4 H 6 D F T + E C 4 H 6 Z P E ) ] In equations 2 and 3, A signifies the surface area, Etotal denotes the energy of total system (surface with adsorbed species) and Eneat signifies the energy of neat ceria surface. According to equation 2, the relative stability of the various plausible configurations is computed with the assumption that the neat ceria surface co-exists in a reservoir of hydrogen and BD molecules. Hydrogenation reactions commence with an input feed that contains hydrogen molecules rather than hydrogen atoms, and hence surface free energies are calculated based on the molecular hydrogen's chemical potential. Similarly, previous studied on the thermodynamic relative stability of metal oxides [32] and halides [33] have utilized the chemical potential of molecular oxygen and chlorine. The summation term of EDFT+EZPE indicates the energy of free molecules. The coefficients x and y also represent number of corresponding adsorbed species over the surface (listed in Table 1). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Single-Molecular adsorption with different site coverage Interaction of molecular hydrogen with ceria surfaces have been comprehensively studied. Literature DFT studies have established that dissociative adsorption of hydrogen molecules forming two surface hydroxyl sites is exothermic in the range of 1.6 – 2.5 eV (per H2 molecule) [34–36]. Heterolytic fission over Ce4+-O2− proceeds with a slightly lower activation barrier in reference to the commonly discussed homolytic dissociation over two oxygen sites. Nonetheless, very facile H diffusion barrier from H-Ce4+ to O2− site eventually affords the products of the homolytic pathway. The latter route incurs an accessible pathway of ∼ 1.0 eV [36]. Our computed dissociation energy of a single hydrogen molecule above the ceria surface amounts to 2.42 eV, i.e., residing at the upper limit of corresponding literature values [34–36].. The formed O-H bonds in all structures falls in the narrow range of 0.97 – 0.99 Å. The latter value coincides with other reported hydroxyl's O-H bonds in ceria surfaces. As shown in Table 1, dissociative adsorption energy of hydrogen molecules noticeably varies with the degree of coverage and with the pre-presence of adsorbed BD molecules. As demonstrated by Fernández-Torre et al. [36], this trend is attributed to a lattice strain induced by more spacious Ce3+ ions when compared with the Ce4+ ions. As the Ө H increases, offsetting lattice relaxation effects coupled with atomic charge localization engender surface OH* groups attached to Ce3+ sites to be less stable at higher concentrations. In line with this remark, Fig. 4 portrays prominent geometric parameters, most notably Ce-O and Ce-Ce distances, where a an expansion is observed in certain Ce-Ce interatomic distances with the Ө H. Likewise, and as Table 1 shows, adsorption energies for the BD molecules consistently decreases by an increment of ∼ 0.10 eV per an added molecule. The considered 2 × 2 unitcell (with a relatively surface area of ∼ 234 Å2) can accommodate four BD molecules with very minimal lateral interaction between the adjacent adsorbed hydrocarbon adducts. For instance, in the B-4 structure, each adsorbed BD molecules departs by at least 4.5 Å from other adjacent molecules. Attempts to re-position co-adsorbed BD molecules have resulted in similar magnitudes of adsorption energies. Thus, the gradual decrease in the binding energy (per adsorbed BD molecule) is ascribed to a noticeable surface relaxation; a trend that also prevails in case of hydrogen adsorption as described above. Optimized geometries for the adsorbed BD structures reveal a noticeable elongation in surface Ce-Ce bonds by ∼ 0.2 Å in reference to the neat surface. The formed C-O bond remains in the range of 1.46 – 1.48 Å in the B-1, B-2, B-3, and B-4 configurations. Fig. 5 plots Δ G a d values for adsorption of pure hydrogen and BD molecules as a function of temperature at 1 atm. As can be seen in Fig. 5., the surface free energy has a direct relationship with the number of hydrogen and BD molecules over the ceria surface. Inspection of Δ G a d values for dissociative adsorption of hydrogen indicates a marginal variation with temperature at low Ө H (Fig. 5a). Fully hydroxylated oxygen sites afford the thermodynamically most stable configurations. Similar finding was recently attained by Li et al. [37]. However, this conclusion holds valid only for stochiometric surfaces whereas the creation of oxygen vacancies (not considered in this work) renders structures with hydrides (Ce-H) to be more stable. As confirmed by XPS measurements, formation of surface OH groups facilitates the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ in switchable oxidation nature of ceria [38, 39]. Subsequent creation of Ce3++VO vacant sites also leads to easier H2 dissociation at the same time [12, 14]. From Fig. 5b, adsorption of the BD molecule becomes an endothermic process as the temperature increases; most notably when more than one molecule is adsorbed. We envisage that carrying out DRIFTS experiments would reveal the interaction nature between the BD molecules (and involved hydrocarbon intermediates) with the ceria surface. The primary objective is to assess the capacity of neat ceria materials in mediating selective hydrogenation of long-chain alkenes beyond the previously demonstrated case of acetylene. 3.2 Co-adsorption of Butadiene and Hydrogen Figure 6 illustrates Δ G a d values for co-adsorption of BD and H2 molecules between 300 – 1500 K and 1 atm. Corresponding chemical potential values at these conditions are given in the upper x-axis in Fig. 5. Table 2 enlists corresponding values Δ G a b s a d . As inferred from Table 2, five structures with high hydrogen coverage ratio incurs very comparable absolute surface free energies, and hence higher thermodynamic stability. Trends of Δ G a d values shown in Fig. 5 reflects similar stability ordering. The fact that co-mixed structures with high Ө H are more thermodynamically “feasible” than corresponding structures with low hydrogen coverage, is intuitively appealing from an experimental point of view. Hydrogenation reactions over ceria surfaces are typically carried out at high ratio of hydrogen to the feed, i.e., 20 to 1 [6]. The region of relative thermodynamic stability is highlighted in Fig. 6. However, it should be noted that structures with comparable surface energies should also co-exist bearing in mind that the close difference in surface energies among the five highlighted structures (from Table 2) fall within the expected accuracy benchmark of the calculations. The effect of hydrogen adsorption on the surface energies of the mixed configurations is more profound than that of the BD molecule. This is due to energetically favoured nature of surface reduction leading to formation of CeO2- x via hydroxyl groups compared to its reduction by molecular butadiene adsorption [40] . 3.3 Electronic analysis Fig. 7 illustrates the total density of states (DOS) of neat ceria, two hydroxylated configurations (namely, the H-0.25 and H-1.00 structures) and the B-1 structure. As can be seen in the DOS diagrams, ceria displays a semi-conductor with band gap of 1.60 eV (Fig. 7.a). The obtained band gap of pure ceria reasonably matches the previously reported corresponding literature values [41]. According computed DOS curves, partially hydroxylated ceria (H-0.25, Fig. 7.b) retains a semiconducting character while at full hydrogen coverage, a metallic character is clearly observed (Fig. 7c). The charge donated by these hydroxyl groups is transferred to the surface Ce atoms resulting in the metallic character at high hydrogen coverage. This is also indicative of formation of a hydrogen-induced electric layer at the interface which contributes to surface conductivity [37] Similarly, adsorption of BD molecules and their co-adsorption with hydrogen systematically reduces the band gap. As Fig. 7.d depicts, adsorption of a single BD molecule reduces the band gap to ∼ 1.0 eV decreases. This could be ascribed to the partial charge transfer from hydrocarbon cut to the oxide which leads to slight changes in surface charges [42] 3.4 Mechanism for Hydrogenation of BD over Ceria In our previous work on the selective hydrogenation of acetylene into ethene over Mo2N surfaces [43], we have demonstrated that its occurrence stems from kinetic and well as thermodynamic factors. Higher surface stability of adsorbed C2H2 enables its surface hydrogenation into C2H4. Reaction barriers for further hydrogenation of C2H4 significantly exceeds its desorption energy. This clearly shut downs the full hydrogenation route into ethane. DFT studies [44, 45] on the selective hydrogenation of BD into 1-butene over other surfaces, have also documented a similar elucidation for the occurrence of partial selective hydrogenation. Figures 8 and 8 display potential energy surfaces for the partial and full hydrogenation routes; respectively. In finding transition structures, computations commenced from hydrogen pre-adsorbed configurations where the hydrogen atoms are positioned in the vicinity of the target carbon atom. It is generally viewed that dissociative hydrogen over O2− sites (with a well-documented barrier of ∼ 1.0 eV) signifies bottleneck in the ceria-assisted partial hydrogenation reactions [14]. Our mapped out potential energy surfaces in case of BD molecules supports this consensus; i.e., barriers for the two required hydrogen transfer reactions resides lower than that of hydrogen dissociative adsorption. Fig. 8 depicts pathways that operate in the partial hydrogenation of BD into 1-butene. The hydrogenation reaction commences with adsorption of a BD molecule via its C2 (refer to carbon atom numberings in Fig. 8a) over an oxygen surface site. Table 3 enlists bond lengths in the adsorbed hydrocarbon cut and its bonding with the surface (i.e., C2-O*). To track the electronic changes along the reaction pathway, Table 4 provides atomic charges on C2 and O* atoms. The adsorption process is exothermic by 0.42 eV and results in the formation of the M1 configuration. H transfer to C4 produces the adsorbed intermediate CH2-CH(O)-CH˙-CH3 adduct through a modest reaction barrier of 0.37 eV. The M2 structure resides 0.32 eV lower than the entrance channel. Upon the adsorption, the C1-C2 bond elongates by ∼ 0.08 Å (in reference to a gas phase BD molecule) indicating an activation of the adsorbed adduct. The C2-C3 bond experiences similar elongation. The formed C2-O* amounts to 1.446 Å and remains within the range 1.421 – 1.475 Å along the partial hydrogenation pathway (Fig. 8). As shown in Table 4, adsorption of the BD molecule caused a partial reduction in the O* site whereas its electronegative charge noticeably reduces by 0.137 e (in reference to the neat surface). The first H transfer reaction leaves C3 as an electron deficient site (-0.260 e). This eases the second hydrogen transfer step as Fig. 8b depicts with a very low barrier of 0.18 eV (TS2). Inspection of bond distances of TS2 (Table 3) discloses a gradual increase in the C3-C4 bond length following the route M3 → TS2 → M4, i.e., featuring the appearance of a single C-C bond in the 1-butene molecule. The M4 configuration represents an adsorbed 1-butene molecule with a C2-O* distance at 1.421 Å. Desorption of the 1-butene molecule is noticeably endothermic by 0.87 eV and concludes the partial hydrogenation route. With the shallow barrier of TS1 and TS2, desorption of 1-butene represents the rate limiting step in the partial hydrogenation BD → 1-butene pathway. Fig. 9 presents the two hydrogen transfer steps that mark the full hydrogenation pathway, i.e., 1-butene into n-butane. As shown in Fig. 9b, the first hydrogen transfer into C1 site encounters a very low barrier of 0.16 eV (TS3) and proceeds in a noticeably exothermic reaction of 0.78 eV. As expected, this step significantly elongates the C1-C2 distances as shown in Table 3 (M5 versus M7). This reaction also accumulates significant positive charge on C2 (Table 4). Pathways shown in Fig. 9b unequivocally elucidate why the full hydrogenation route is unfeasible. Hydrogen transfer to C2 site (attached to O*) demands a very sizable barrier of 2.75 eV via the transition structure TS4 in an endothermic reaction of 0.70 eV. This high barrier stems from the involved C-O bond's rupture. With a bond distance of 1.386 Å and clearly contrasted atomic charges (0.04 e - -0.658 e), the C2-O* bond in M8 clearly signifies a tangible carbon-oxygen chemical bond. In TS4, the C2-O separation amounts to 2.371 Å marking the bond's fission. Desorption of the formed n-butane molecule requires only 0.26 eV as the desorption energy. In short, the fate of the M8 intermediate is to undergo back hydrogen migration to the surface (M7 → TS3 → M6, through an energy penalty of 0.94 eV) rather than to ensue through further hydrogenation (M8 → TS4 → M9, with an energy penalty of 2.75 eV). In case of partial hydrogenation, the M2 adduct arises via further hydrogenation (M3 → M4 via 0.18 eV) rather than back hydrogen shift to the surface (M2 → TS1→ M1 via 0.27 eV). As has been recently demonstrated in case of acetylene hydrogenation over Pd [46], other factors such as coverage effects may induce a noticeable effect on activity and selectivity. Such aspects will be investigated in a due course for the system at hand. 4 Conclusion The study presented thermodynamics and kinetic account that underline the partial hydrogenation of BD molecules into 1-butene. Electronic analysis disclosed a shift of ceria surface into a metallic character at high Ө H. Offsetting lattice relaxation effects reduces the binding energies of both hydrogen and BD at high coverage. Computed surface free energies for adsorbed BD/H configurations indicate a higher thermodynamic stability for surfaces with their Ө H residing in the high range of 0.60 to 0.95. The obtained stability trend based on absolute surface free energies remain unchanged when the chemical potential is incorporated. Energy profiles have been mapped out to elucidate a mechanistic rational for the expected preferential occurrence of selective rather than full hydrogenation of the BD molecule. Hydrogen transfer reactions that govern the partial hydrogenation route ensue via facile reaction barriers. Releasing n-butane molecule from the surface should be impeded in view of the very sizable energy barrier required to break the carbon-O* bond. Obtained energies demonstrate that the fate of the intermediate in the full hydrogenation pathway is to de-hydrogenate rather than to further hydrogenate. coredata.dc:description: Distinctive redox properties and structural defects have made ceria a desirable choice for selective hydrogenation reactions for a wide array of hydrocarbons. In this work, we have studied – via density functional theory (DFT) calculations - selective hydrogenation of 1,3-butadiene into 1-butene over ceria catalyst. This reaction entails strategic applications in petroleum industries. Adsorption and surface energies for various co-adsorbed 1,3-butadaiene/hydrogen configurations were computed based on the ab initio atomistic thermodynamic formalism. The thermodynamically most stable configurations correspond to surfaces with high hydrogen surface coverage. This finding coincides with the commonly deployed high ratio of hydrogen to hydrocarbons in hydrogenation reactions over ceria. A consistent decrease in binding energies of multiple 1,3-butadiene adsorptions (per adsorbed molecule) is ascribed to a noticeable surface relaxation effects rather than to lateral interactions between adjacent adsorbed molecules. The partial hydrogenation route 1,3-butadiene →1-butene proceeds via accessible energy barriers and involves hydrogen transfer from OH* groups to surface-unbounded carbon sites. Desorption of the formed 1-butene constitutes a bottleneck in the partial hydrogenation route. The occurrence of full hydrogenation into n-butane is unfeasible in view of the high energy barrier encountered in the final hydrogen migration step to a surface-bounded carbon atom.
